title: The Temples of Delwädä
subtitle: Section I.3 from JAB Manual 5th edition 2024

storyContent.tagHTML: On Mount Äbu in Rajasthan stand two magnificent Jain temples known as the Delwädä Temples. Their intricate marble carvings are so breathtaking they are called "poetry in marble." The first was built by Vimalshä in the 11th century, and the second, Lunaga Vasahi, by two brothers, Vastupäl and Tejpäl, in the 13th century.

Vimalshä was a capable and outstanding commander during the Solanki dynasty's golden period in Gujarat. As a young man, he was known for his skill in horseback riding and archery. He and his intelligent brother Nedh joined the service of King Bhimdev in the capital city of Pätan. Nedh became a chancellor, and Vimal became a commander, marrying a beautiful woman named Shridevi.

Some courtiers grew jealous of Vimalshä's success. They noticed he would only bow to the Tirthankars before anyone else, even the king. They poisoned the king's mind, telling him Vimalshä was arrogant and might even try to take the throne. Growing suspicious, King Bhimdev turned against Vimalshä.

Feeling the king's distrust, Vimalshä left Pätan and went to Mount Äbu (then called Chandraväti). There, he defeated the local chief, Dhandhuk, who was trying to rebel against King Bhimdev. Vimalshä took control of the region in the king's name, acting as its governor.

Vimalshä and his wife had no children. He met a Jain Ächärya, Dharmaghosh-suri, and felt deep remorse for the violence in his past wars. The Ächärya advised him to build a temple to atone for his sins. Vimalshä also prayed to the goddess Ambikä Devi, who offered him a choice: a son, or the ability to build a great temple. Vimalshä chose the temple.

The project was immense. It took 14 years and cost a fortune. Artisans were brought from far away, and there wasn't even a road up the mountain. Vimalshä famously paid the sculptors in gold equal to the weight of the marble dust they carved each day. The result was a temple of such exquisite beauty that it is considered a world wonder.
Two brothers, Vastupäl and Tejpäl, were faithful ministers to King Vir-Dhaval of Gujarat. Tejpäl's wife, Anupamä-devi, was a wise and religious woman whose opinion he greatly respected.

Once, while on a pilgrimage, the brothers decided to bury their wealth to keep it safe from robbers. As they were digging, they discovered a huge pot of jewels and coins. Unsure what to do with the unexpected treasure, Tejpäl asked his wife.

Anupamä-devi wisely replied that wealth from a deep trench should be placed on a high mountain to spread the glory of Jainism. Taking her advice, the brothers decided to use the treasure to build the second great temple on Mount Äbu, the Lunaga Vasahi Temple. In this temple, Tejpäl dedicated two special niches, known as "Deräni-Jethäni nä Gokhla," to commemorate his wife and his sister-in-law.

events.title: Early Life
events.description: Vimal and his brother Nedh are raised by their mother. Vimal becomes an expert archer and equestrian, while Nedh becomes a wise scholar.

events.title: Success in Pätan
events.description: The brothers move to the capital city of Pätan. Vimal joins the army and Nedh joins the royal court. Under King Bhimdev, Vimal becomes a commander and Nedh a chancellor.

events.title: Jealousy and Exile
events.description: Jealous courtiers make King Bhimdev suspicious of Vimalshä. To escape the king's distrust, Vimalshä leaves Pätan for Mount Äbu.

events.title: A Vow for a Temple
events.description: Feeling remorse for past violence, Vimalshä is advised by Ächärya Dharmaghosh-suri to build a temple. He chooses this sacred task over having a son when offered a choice by the goddess Ambikä Devi.

events.title: Construction Begins
events.description: Vimalshä buys land and begins the difficult 14-year project, bringing marble and artisans from far away to the top of the mountain.

events.title: Temple Completion
events.description: The magnificent temple, the first at Delwädä, is completed at a cost of 185,300,000 gold coins. Its carvings are considered a wonder of the world.

timelineData.era: Vastupäl, Tejpäl, and the Second Temple

events.title: The Two Brothers
events.description: Vastupäl and Tejpäl are faithful ministers serving King Vir-Dhaval in Gujarat.

events.title: A Fortunate Discovery
events.description: While on a pilgrimage, the brothers try to bury their wealth for safety but instead unearth a huge pot of treasure.

events.title: A Wife's Wise Counsel
events.description: Unsure what to do, Tejpäl asks his wise wife, Anupamä-devi. She advises that the wealth from the earth should be used to build something high on a mountain.

events.title: Lunaga Vasahi is Built
events.description: Inspired, the brothers build the second Delwädä temple, Lunaga Vasahi, in memory of their elder brother. It includes niches called 'Deräni-Jethäni nä Gokhla' to honor their wives.

charactersData.name: Vimalshä
charactersData.description: A brave and capable commander under King Bhimdev. He built the first, incredibly ornate Delwädä temple on Mount Äbu to atone for sins committed in war.

charactersData.name: Vastupäl & Tejpäl
charactersData.description: Two brothers who served as ministers in Gujarat. After discovering a hidden treasure, they used it to build the second Delwädä temple, Lunaga Vasahi.

charactersData.name: Anupamä-devi
charactersData.description: The wise and religious wife of Tejpäl. It was her suggestion to use the found treasure to build a temple on a mountain, leading to the creation of Lunaga Vasahi.

charactersData.name: King Bhimdev
charactersData.description: The king of the Solanki dynasty in Gujarat. He initially favored Vimalshä but grew suspicious due to the lies of jealous courtiers.

charactersData.name: Dharmaghosh-suri
charactersData.description: The Jain Ächärya who saw Vimalshä's genuine repentance and advised him to build a temple.

charactersData.name: Ambikä Devi
charactersData.description: The goddess who granted Vimalshä's wish to build a temple, forcing him to choose it over having a son.

quizData.question: Who built the first temple at Delwädä?
Who built the second temple, known as Lunaga Vasahi?
Why did Vimalshä leave the court of King Bhimdev?
quizData.answer: Because jealous courtiers made the king suspicious of him.

quizData.question: When given a choice by the goddess Ambikä Devi, what did Vimalshä choose instead of a son?
quizData.answer: The ability to build a great temple.

quizData.question: How long did it take to build Vimalshä's temple?
How did Vastupäl and Tejpäl get the wealth to build the second temple?
quizData.answer: They unearthed a large pot of jewels and coins while trying to bury their own wealth.

quizData.question: Whose idea was it to use the found treasure to build a temple on a mountain?
What are the niches dedicated to the ministers' wives in the second temple called?
The Delwädä temples are often described as...
In which mountain range are the Delwädä temples located?

graphicsData.title: Jealousy at Court
graphicsData.description: Courtiers, envious of Vimalshä's success, tell King Bhimdev that Vimalshä is arrogant and a threat to the throne.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Jealous courtiers whisper to King Bhimdev, pointing at Vimalshä.

graphicsData.title: A Fateful Choice
graphicsData.description: The goddess Ambikä Devi offers Vimalshä a choice: a son, or the ability to build a great temple. He chooses the temple.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Vimalshä kneels before the glowing goddess Ambikä Devi.

graphicsData.title: Poetry in Marble
graphicsData.description: For 14 years, the finest sculptors create breathtakingly intricate carvings. Vimalshä pays them in gold equal to the weight of the marble dust they produce.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Artisans carefully carve intricate details into the marble ceilings of the Delwädä temple.

graphicsData.title: A Hidden Treasure
graphicsData.description: While trying to hide their own wealth, the brothers Vastupäl and Tejpäl discover a massive hidden treasure.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Vastupäl and Tejpäl look amazed as they unearth a large pot filled with gold coins and jewels.

graphicsData.title: A Wife's Wisdom
graphicsData.description: Tejpäl's wife, Anupamä-devi, gives him profound advice on what to do with the newfound wealth.
graphicsData.dialogue: Anupamä-devi: "This wealth came from a deep trench, but the right place for it is on a high mountain."
graphicsData.imageAlt: Anupamä-devi wisely speaks to her husband Tejpäl.

graphicsData.title: Lunaga Vasahi
graphicsData.description: Inspired by the advice, the brothers build the second great temple at Delwädä, with special niches to honor their wives.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The completed Lunaga Vasahi temple stands magnificently on Mount Äbu.
